awd_titl_txt: Synthesis of New Precursors for Vapor Deposition
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project led by Professor Roy Gordon. Professor Gordon is a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry at Harvard University.  In this project, he is discovering new compounds that contain important metals for the fabrication of faster and more energy-efficient computers and enable the transmission of electrical energy over longer distances, as required for using more clean and renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, and hydro power. The goal is to make the new compounds so that they are suitable for depositing the metals onto heated surfaces so that they can then be used in the construction of new devices. At the current time, none of the known compounds that contain these metals have the properties needed for this effort. The project employs techniques from organic, inorganic, and materials chemistry. Professor Gordon trains a wide range of students, including those from groups currently underrepresented in science, and he participates in a range of outreach activities that include the design of new exhibits at the Boston Museum of Science.

This project is synthesizing novel divalent and trivalent metals of groups 4, 5, and 6 supported by amidinate, guanidinate, and cyclopentadienyl ligands. Initial targets are relatives of known Ti(III) and V(III) amidinates, followed by more ambitious targets, including compounds of Ti(II), Zr(III), Hf(III), Nb(II), Nb(III), and Mo(III). The fundamental knowledge gained in the project may help to solve important technological problems, including deposition of smaller interconnects for computers, and making superconducting wires for the long-distance transmission of electricity. Particularly important targets are Ti(II) compounds, for which no examples are known with the desired combination of properties: volatility, thermal stability, and high reactivity. The chosen ligands combine steric and electronic properties expected to stabilize highly reactive Ti(II) compounds. Similar strategies are being explored for Zr, Hf, V, Nb and Mo, for which only a few compounds even come close to combining all of these desired properties. The project also provides technical input toward the design of new museum exhibits on sustainability, energy conservation, and renewable energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This work resulted in several advancements along different frontiers of vapor deposition research with application to the semiconductor industry. The first accomplishment, the successful deposition of copper halide layers by pulsed chemical vapor deposition (CVD) using a copper beta-diketonate precursor, opens new avenues for the use of copper halides in the semiconductor industry. Copper halides are a promising material for use as transparent p-type semiconductors, including in thin-film photovoltaic cells. The pulsed CVD process afforded continuous films of CuBr at temperatures between 65 and 10°C with growth rates of ≤1 nm/min it may be adapted to produce CuX from any hydrogen halide, HX. This work was presented at a conference and in a journal article, resulted in a graduate thesis, and led to a patent with potential applications to thin-film solar cells.

The second accomplishment, the demonstration of epitaxial deposition of MgxCa1-xO on SiC and -Ga2O3 by atomic layer deposition (ALD), expands the range of possible gate dielectric layers suitable for wide-band gap power transistors. MgxCa1-xO was determined to form an epitaxial layer on both SiC(000l) and β-Ga2O3 by transmission electron microscopy and XRD rocking curve scans. Mg and Ca amidinate precursors were held at temperatures below 150 degrees Celsius and the deposition temperature was 310 degrees Celsius. The ability to deposit      MgxCa1-xO on SiC and β-Ga2O3 with epitaxial quality opens new possibilities for the use of these materials in enhancement-mode metal-oxide field effect transistors with low interfacial defects and leakage currents. This work resulted in two journal articles.

The third accomplishment was the successful deposition of silver and gold by ALD with hydrogen as a reductant at temperatures below 230 degrees Celsius. This result demonstrated the high thermal stability of the bicyclic amidinate precursors to deposit gold and silver thin-films with resistivities near their bulk values. The bicyclic nature of these ligands eliminates the instability caused by -methyl and -hydride migration. This work resulted in a journal article and a patent.

The fourth accomplishment, the development and demonstration of atmospheric pressure chemical vapor deposition (APCVD) of methylammonium bromide and tin(II) bromide, suggest the promise of this technique for making metal-halide perovskites at commercially relevant rates. This work showed by XRD the first reported deposition of textured methylammonium bromide and tin(II) bromide by APCVD and highlighted a potentially fruitful avenue for optimizing the deposition process through chemical-kinetics coupled computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations. This work resulted in a graduate thesis.

The fifth accomplishment was the development of a novel liquid tin(II) formamidinate precursor for use in making tin(II) sulfide. This new precursor was substantially volatile at the deposition temperatures and, as a liquid, convenient for direct liquid injection (DLI) CVD schemes for vaporization. This precursor was utilized by ALD to make tin(II) sulfide thin-films, which were characterized to be of a previously unknown tin(II) sulfide crystal phase. This work resulted in a journal article.           

In conclusion, these accomplishments represent significant advancements in the field of semiconductor technology. The successful deposition of cuprous bromide, mixed metal oxides, silver and gold, methylammonium bromide, and tin(II) bromide and sulfide by various CVD and ALD processes opens up new avenues for the use of these materials in the semiconductor industry and in other applications.


Last Modified: 05/09/2023
Modified by: Roy G Gordon
